newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Deve Gowda cut from different cloth.
newsitem.headline: India's Deve Gowda cut from different cloth.

text.p: Caretaker Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda once said there were better leaders for his post but many compatriots considered him the right man at the right time.

He was thrust into power after winning a parliamentary vote of confidence in June 1996, ending several weeks of political turmoil following inconclusive general elections in the world's biggest democracy.
On April 11, he resigned after being soundly defeated in another crucial vote of confidence in his minority government, triggered by a key ally's shock decision to withdraw support last month.
And on Saturday, he announced that outgoing foreign minister Inder Kumar Gujral would succeed him as the head of the centre-left United Front coalition and prime minister.
Sixty-three year old Deve Gowda became India's third prime minister in a month when he was sworn in last June by President Shankar Dayal Sharma. But he did not let the promotion go to his head.
With some deft footwork, he managed to hold together for longer than some people believed possible a 13-group coalition ranging from social democrats to communists.
"There is no doubt that there are better leaders in our Front," Deve Gowda told The Week magazine after being named prime minister. "I am not the most competent man."
He won the job almost by default after an octogenarian communist was tripped up by his own party and a right-wing Hindu nationalist fell short of a parliamentary majority.
Deve Gowda is cut from different cloth than his predecessors, a reflection of India's rapidly changing political culture where regional interests and lower castes are flexing their muscles.
A southern leader from peasant stock, Deve Gowda contrasts with the northern, urban, upper caste Brahmins who have dominated Indian politics since independence in 1947.
"I am a born fighter," Deve Gowda said. "Throughout my life I have swum against the current. I am a self-made man. I represent the poor."
He had never held office before in the federal capital, New Delhi, and speaks little Hindi, the dominant language in the north.
"He is a very representative product of the previously marginalised India which is now in the majority," said Ashis Nandy, of the Centre for the Study of Developing Societies.
"I find him very refreshing."
Haradanahalli Doddegowda Deve Gowda's most distinguishing biographical feature is perhaps his rural roots.

His father tilled a modest one-acre (0.4-hectare) plot of land in the southern section of Karnataka state. The family is from the Vokkaliga community, a group of farmers from an intermediary Hindu caste who wield power in the region.
Deve Gowda helped his father grow cereals on the farm, but also went to school and earned a degree in civil engineering.
Since 1962, when he was elected to the Karnataka state assembly, Deve Gowda has been a full-time politician.
"I have worked in the field, wearing a vest and shorts. We have lived in a hut sleeping on a potato sack and covering ourselves with another sack," he said.
Deve Gowda likes to be called a son of the soil and is a member of the socialist Janata Dal party. But he is no enemy of industry or money.
"His heart beats for the rural poor but that does not mean he is anti-rich," said D.M. Nanjundappa, deputy chairman of Karnataka's planning board.
Deve Gowda impressed a U.S. business mission led by the late commerce secretary Ron Brown, who visited Karnataka in 1994 after Deve Gowda was named chief minister for the second time.
In Brown's presence, the state leader expressed unambiguous support for a big power project led by U.S. firm Cogentrix.

Later he aggressively pursued protesters who ransacked a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant, owned by U.S. food giant Pepsico Inc, in Karnataka's capital Bangalore. The protesters opposed the entry of foreign multinationals into India.
A vegetarian and a teetotaller, Deve Gowda is married and has four sons and two daughters.
